pros: Good pay, Easy, Decent coworkers

review_title: Loved the job. Hated being stretched too thin to do it well.
pros: Fabulous technical team Flexible schedule as staffing allowed Opportunity to work with clinical teams for continuous patient care improvements
cons: Laboratory staffing issues comparable to most other facilities (limited candidate pool, continuous new hire training, abused FMLA, etc.) Continuous change or lack of management (5 managers in 8 years)

pros: There is nothing redeeming about this hospital
cons: Very toxic place to work; a lot of backstabbing among employees; if they don’t like you, they will push you out. when I was offered the job, I had told them I had a 10 day vacation already planned. they indicated they would have no problem accommodating it because I informed them before I accepted the job. When I started, they said I needed to find coverage for my working days. Also, once I started, my job description changed. I was not hired for OR, therefore, there wouldn’t be any call; once at work, they said OR is required with call

review_title: Good for a public hospital but not great
pros:
- Many team members are great
- Wellness competitions for things like free state Park pass or gift cards
- Insurance is pretty good coverage wise
- if you work at the hospital there is good food at the bistro/cafeteria.
- pay is decent but could be better
-PTO accrual is decent and will be upped a little at your 2/5/10yr marks.
cons:
-Annual raises are low even for top performers.
-Insurance costs are high, even for singles
-holidays and sick day pay come out of your accrued PTO 
-401k match is only 3%
- culture of micromanaging both by peers and leaders
- not much room for career growth unless you don't mind waiting for people to retire

pros: good atmosphere, good teamwork, critical incentive shifts
cons: high stress, every other weekend

pros: Some of the coworkers I work with are good.
cons:
-No recognition by management for extending shifts, picking up shifts, going above and beyond in work, or enduring physical harm in the line of work.

-Very clique-y department. Lots of favoritism in management.

-Strong workers are fired because they're not personal friends with management. Weak and slacking workers are kept around.

-The nurses will dump everything on you, even if it's outside of what we are trained to do. You will be the one reprimanded if you don't do it.

-Nurses also have a very "us vs. them" mind set, especially the ER nurses. Massive superiority complexes all around.

-The benefits are not worth it. Pay is low in comparison to the other hospitals in the area.

-No office space. Less than 120 sq. ft. expected to fit ~8-12 people at shift change while maintaining social distancing.

-Management doesn't care about you. They care about making themselves look good in the eyes of their superiors and that is it.

pros: Co-workers were excellent. Boss was helpful and supportive.
cons: High stress at times difficult cases

pros: The teamwork at Meriter is one of the best parts of the position, as most people at Meriter are rather cheerful and easy to get along with. You accumulate PTO fairly fast after your probationary period as well
cons: The inpatient pharmacy has no sense of work-life balance, as you are expected to work up to 7 or 8 days at a time, and the salary is too low despite the intensity of the work to afford to take days off

pros:
Great benefits
3%, 401k match
Decent vacation -better the longer you stay
cons:
Often understaffed
High burnout/turnover in management

review_title: Avoid Some Units Like the Plague
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Madison, WI
pros:
- Decent staffing, up to 9 patients (some facilities are a lot worse)
- Great pay
- Very thorough training if you have no experience
cons:
- MAJOR BULLYING PROBLEMS ON SOME UNITS
- RNs refuse to do CNA work, don't expect any help
- Managers blame systemic problems on you
- Lots of gossip, cliquey
- Reports go uninvestigated (see their NICU abuse scandal)

job_title: Mental Health Specialist in Madison, WI
pros: Merite is a great employer, the team at CAP is supportive, and the job can be very fun and fulfilling.
cons: Can have difficult patients that challenge staff and boundaries. Often asked to work extra hours over FTE

review_title: I Would Be Hard-Pressed to Leave!
job_title: Senior Laboratory Technician in Madison, WI
pros:
THE LAB FAMILY IS AWESOME! Our team has been known to bend over backwards to help each other out, whether it is for coverage of an unexpected leave, baby shower planning/hosting, support following a death in the family, etc.

Competitive pay with annual performance evaluation (After completing 1 year of employment, MLT pay increases to MT pay!)
Earned time (vacation) accrual
Schedule flexibility and coworkers that are willing to trade/pickup shifts
401K employer contribution
Tuition reimbursement
Leadership, from Manager to CEO, is very engaged and promotes career growth and skill development (Our Core Lab Manager, Director, and current CEO started out in our lab!)
Continuing education opportunities
cons: Filling open positions as our senior staff retire has been a struggle in recent years, as with most other laboratories.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Madison, WI
pros: Best paid CNA job in the Midwest. Good people work here
cons: Facilities aren't quite as nice as UW

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Madison, WI
pros: Great Co workers who are like family
cons: Long hours that can be stressful

job_title: Health Unit Coordinator (HUC) in Madison, WI
pros: Caring administrators, decent pay, friendly coworkers
cons: Some supervisors are not easily approachable or visible. I am very intimidated by my managers.

job_title: Senior Medical Lab Technician in Madison, WI
pros: Engaged/involved management, decent benefits, community/employee-oriented culture
cons: Lab IS system is outdated

pros: Competitive pay to other hospitals.
cons: No incentive pay to pick up shifts even though asked to pick up on a weekly basis.

pros: Many employees have been around a long time.  this is helpful in the fact that they have a great deal of knowledge about their jobs.  Most are willing to lend a hand and step outside of their comfort zones in order to work as a team.  THe benefits are great.  Health insurance premiums are low, paid time off includes sick and personal days as well as all the holidays.  There are opportunties to move to different positions as Meriter really likes to retain current employees and hire from within.  This allows them to keep
cons: Lots of cliques.  But you have those no matter where you work.  It is hard to get in unless you know someone who already works there and can put in the good word for you.  The application process is also quite long and drawn out.  The interview process is tedious.  You can expect three or more interviews beofre you have a clue one way or the other if an offer is going to come through.  You can expect three or more interviews before you have a clue one way or the other if an offer is going to come through.

review_title: BEST HOSPITAL TO WORK FOR IN MADISON
pros:
Benefits for both full-time and eligible part-time employees
Great pay with fair appraisal processes
Guaranteed hours based on FTE
Tuition Reimbursement after 1 year of employment
Paid uniforms 
Various free company sponsored events
Awesome co-workers and management
cons:
Have to pay for parking (apprx. $18 per pay check --> $36/month) to park in the hospital ramp that is always undergoing construction in the spring/summer and dangerously icy in the winter
Surprisingly high employee turnover especially in entry level positions 
Management is mostly great, however some of them can be useless birds
Communication within departments could be better
Little to no career advancement unless you pursue education specifically related

pros: I'm a physician employed by Meriter, in the Meriter Medical Group.  Meriter is pouring resources into this group, and sincerely seems interested in develop the group into a quality group that is competitive in all respects to other multispecialty groups.  Management has improved vastly from five years ago, and the current CEO and COO are stellar.
cons: Any hospital has it's bureaucratic issues, and Meriter is no exception.  At times it seems difficult to effect small changes or improvements without undue process or delay, especially if money is involved.

pros: Friendly co-workers, beautiful office settings, generally amicable patient base, many informative meetings about upcoming workplace changes, free parking
cons: while there are many informative meetings about upcoming changes, the purpose of the changes is to maintain current patient base and to means to grow the patient base in a region where Meriter is the underdog in the new Obamacare environment.  So things are as staffing lean as possible with overtime strongly discouraged yet patient needs are to be met cheerfully but within office hours.

review_title: Total disconnect between management and clinical staff
pros: Serving and supporting health, spirit, and healing for patients and families; terrific co-workers; RN's treated better than other support staff, wonderful Palliative Care Team, some good physicians, good cardiac unit.
cons: Extremely deceitful management, focused only on bottom line, to detriment of patient and family care and staff morale; poor communication of goals (change often); financially reward top management much more than deserved; lowered reputation in community in past few years, lack of awareness of connection between excellent/adequate spiritual care and pt healing: just not well-integrated across disciplines. As with all healthcare, too much RN leadership and not enough representation of other disciplines (and I'm an RN!).

review_title: Best Hospital Work Environment that I've Experienced
pros:
Really great staff, all willing to teach and very knowledgeable.
Supportive management.
Resources like Nurse Educators or IV Teams ("Vascular Access"), Voceras, EKG team, which I never saw from any other hospital. 
Seriously the best cleaning staff I've ever seen. 
Protocols and policies are clear and easy to access. 
Respectful doctors and residents who don't put you down.
Affordable on-site parking.
Competitive pay with consistent yearly raises.
Good training with actual classes (not including nurse residency, which is entirely separate) for new hires. 
Consistent "on one week, off one week" schedule, which was surprising since it's a hospital unit. 
CEO is approachable and easy to contact if needed.
From my experience and unit, (most) nurses don't eat their young here.
cons:
Pay could be better.
No 401K contribution matching, which was surprising. All of my previous employers offered this. 
No tuition reimbursement until 1 year if employment, also really surprising. 
Paying for parking. Some hospitals offer it for free. It's only $18 per paycheck, but still... 
Getting "ticketed" in the employee ramp for minor mistakes (parking on a line, etc). 
Rotating shifts. 
Working every other weekend (the worst part). 
The hospital layout is not the best. It's pretty confusing giving people directions, since the "East" and "north" wings don't make sense, and some of the floor levels don't line up. 

The MRI room requires special IV pumps, so you have to switch everything when you go there. This is such a hassle. 

One of my biggest concerns is that Meriter doesn't offer some of the complex procedures that it used to, especially after creating a "joint agreement" with UW. This includes things like open-heart surgeries, etc. It might limit treatment plans for patients and possibly cause the nurses to lose valuable skills. I know they're working on this, however.

review_title: Great teamwork to treat patients well.
pros: I have worked in a lot of hospitals and Meriter is the best I've been in as far as coordination among team members so that patients have the best care. Communication is better than in most places due to electronic scheduling and Vocera communication system. Disciplines seem willing to help each other without the issues many places have. Good focus on continuing education and improving processes for efficiency.
cons: I wish they had more hours to offer me because I like working there.

pros: Great working environment. Super clean, staff and management is helpful. There are multiple parties and celebration, which includes great food.
cons: There are not too many cons I can think of but when the organization create new polices they have an expectancy for everyone to be on board. Also there are a lot surveys to fill throughout the year.

pros: Flexible work hours, days great wage and benefit programs great night shift diff.  Very little interaction with management.  Friendly atmosphere
cons: Unrealistic work load with little understanding of what my position did at all. Upper management decisions on how to improve that didn't quite fit.

review_title: Great staff great docs and great management
pros:
strong esprit de corps
put patinets first
super friednlya nd caring staff
visible and involved leadership
strong communication from leadership to staff--especially from CEO
cons:
staffing levels always seem to be fluctauting; would be nice to have more balance
always seem to be picked on by cross town rival UW Health

pros: Great people; decent benefits.
cons: Depends on what department and who is running it; some departments were great, other departments had high turnover because no would stay with the managers/directors.

review_title: Very interesting place to work at

cons:

pros: Pay was decent. Benefits seemed good as well (vacation build up was awesome).
cons: Toxic work environment. Horrible work ethic. Managers, supervisors and staff quitting left and right (if they haven't already quit, they're looking to get out). Specific employees lack empathy for patients and fellow coworkers; sweet to the face and horrible behind the backs. Constant bad mouthing of upper management.

pros: Good pay and benefits for 20+ hours a week
cons: Hostile department employees, gossip, complete lack of professionalism by supervisors.

review_title: Working at Meriter was very rewarding.
pros: The management is great and they spend a lot of time rewarding workers.
cons: There is not a great path for continued growth in a position.

pros: Great benefits, great staff and a high standard of care.
cons: Just merged with a large company, lots of changes to fit needs of company as a whole

pros: Good benefits, 30+ paid days off a year.  Great Pay! Union Power!
cons: Hard physical work, buy not excessive.
